abstract.p: Joan Rolnick letter, commenting on recent article, lauds new diversity training program at University of Connecticut, which is ranked 12th by Princeton Review among 20 most homophobic colleges (S)

block.p: After learning that the University of Connecticut ranked 12 among the 20 most homophobic colleges in the Princeton Review, I was pleased to read your article describing in detail the changes that UConn was making.

After learning that the University of Connecticut ranked 12 among the 20 most homophobic colleges in the Princeton Review, I was pleased to read your article describing in detail the changes that UConn was making.

Diversity training, and support (UConn Safe Zone) for gay, lesbian, bisexual or transgender students, among other proposed changes, are of utmost importance. As a member of PFLAG, (parents, family and friends of lesbians and gays), my husband and I have spent many hours in diversity training with teachers and students in area schools. We know how effective this can be.
I would like to make one correction to the article: Being gay is not an alternative life style. Being gay, straight, bisexual or transgender are simply different sexual orientations.
